publications_documents.name: welcome_document
publications_documents.title: Welcome
publications_documents.body: We are currently under construction. Please come back soon as we continue to add content.
publications_documents.notes: This document can be used as a placeholder for sites under construction.

publications_documents.name: error_page
publications_documents.title: Error
publications_documents.notes: This is a general error page where errors can be caught that are not due to the page not being found or access not granted.

publications_documents.name: not_found_page
publications_documents.title: Page Not Found
publications_documents.body: Sorry! The page you requested could not be found.
publications_documents.notes: This page displays when the page requested isn't available to this user due to causes other than access permissions.

publications_documents.name: no_permissions_page
publications_documents.title: No Access
publications_documents.body: Sorry! You do not have access to this page.
publications_documents.notes: This page displays when access is not granted to the current user.

publications_documents.name: sitemap_page
publications_documents.title: Site Map
publications_documents.body: Click on a link to go to the corresponding page.
publications_documents.notes: This page displays a site map of the publications. The publications included in the map are those whose site map flag has been set.

publications_documents.name: doc_publication_types
publications_documents.title: Publication Types
publications_documents.body:
Publication types represent different types of content to be published. There are twelve such types predefined in the Publications module:

  • Blog
  • Catalogue
  • Document
  • Download
  • Events
  • FAQ
  • Generic Publication
  • Picture
  • Quote
  • Review
  • Translation
  • Web Link

Each publication type defines a set of pages with common features. A pubtlication ype will typically a number of content fields, such as title, decription etc. that refer to the content of its pages. These fields will be defined in accordance with the publication types specific requirements. For instance, a web link publiction type icludes a field for web URLS, a FAQ publication type includes fields fro question and answer, and so on.

The definition of each publication type includes a series of configuration fields, that define the "background" properties of its publications. Examples of such fields are start and end publication times, access rules, language etc. These can be set for each document. For instance, one such setting defines whether a publication will be included in the pulbication modules sitemap page. For more information on these settings go here. In general you should not attempt to change the definition of any of the configuration fields.

Each publication type also has configuration fields, which are inherited by its publications unless specifically overridden. These configuration fields can be modified by clicking the "Modify" icon of a publication type here. As an example, one such field defines the publication type's meta keywords. Unless specifically overridden in a page/publication, all the publication type's pages will have the same meta keywords. The publication type in turn inherits some of these fields, such as access rules, from the global settings of the publications module.

Finally, publication types have some configuration settings which apply to all of its pages, such as the sort order of pages in its views. These default values for these settings are inherited from the publication module's global settings. These configuration settings can be modified by clicking the "Configure" icon of a publication type here.

Publication types are fairly flexible. They can be interchanged (e.g. turning a news article type into a documention type) with the caveat that the content of the pages may change in certain cases as a result, depending on which content fields the old and new publication type have.

Each publication type has several default templates. The templates serve to format and display the contents of the publication types pages.  These templates are:

  • input: the input form used to enter content when creating or modifying a page.
  • summary display: the display template used when a group of publications are displayed together, such as a listing of news articles.
  • detail display: the template used to display a single page.

Each publication type is a dd object, and its definition can be modified through the Dynamicdata backend here. It is fairly easy to create new types. This involves cloning an existing type (usually the so called generic publication type), and its templates, and modifying the newly created object appropriately.

publications_documents.name: doc_configurations
publications_documents.title: Configuratiion Settings
publications_documents.description: This page describes the different configuration settings in the publications module and how they interact.
publications_documents.body:
Configuring Publications

Each page/publication has a settings tab which holds its configuration options. These configuration options are checked when the page is modified or displayed. For instance, one such setting defines from when to when a page is displayed. The settings are the same for all pages, and they apply only to their specific page. In other words, even among translations of a given publication, the appropriate settings can be different for each translation.

Many of the page level settings can be inherited from the page's publication type. In general, if a page setting is left empty or undefined, the setting of its publication type will hold.

Configuring Publication Types

Publication types contain two types of configuration settings:

  1. Some settings are default values for the publication type's pages. These can be overridden by the single pages as described above. These settings can be accessed by clicking the "Modify" icon of a publication type here. As an example, one such field defines the publication type's meta keywords. Unless specifically overridden in a page/publication, all the publication type's pages will have the same meta keywords. The publication type in turn inherits some of these fields, such as access rules, from the global settings of the publications module.
  2. Publication types have some configuration settings which apply to all of its pages, such as the sort order of pages in its views. The default values for these settings are inherited from the Publication module's global settings. These configuration settings can be accessed here.

Global Settings

There are a number of global settings which hold for all publication types and pages unless overridden. These can be accessed here.

N.B. Some of these configuration settings are subject to review and may change in the future.

publications_documents.name: doc_publications
publications_documents.title: Publications
publications_documents.description: This page describes publications/pages, the fundamental object of the Publications module
publications_documents.body:
The basic objects that the Publications module works with are publications or pages.

In the simplest case, a publication/page corresponds to a page displayed on a we site. Such pages can take different forms, corresponmding to say articles, FAQ pages, collections of web links, and so on. Each page corresponds to a publication type. For more information on publication types, go here.

Publications, however, need not display content. They can also serve as placeholders or as redirects points to other pages of the Publications module or other modules.

The Publications Tree

Pages are arranged in a tree structure,  which can be browsed here. The stree strucure defines a naturally ordering for the pages, which is reflected in its menus and sitemap (unless overridden).
